{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Use British English|date=June 2015}} {{Insolvency}} '''Cross-border insolvency''' (sometimes called '''international insolvency''') regulates the treatment of financially distressed debtors where such debtors have assets or creditors in more than one country.<ref>{{cite book|title=Insolvency in Private International Law|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|author=Ian Fletcher|edition=2nd|year=2005|isbn=978-0199262502}}</ref> Typically, cross-border insolvency is more concerned with the [[insolvency]] of [[corporation|companies]] that operate in more than one country rather than [[bankruptcy]] of individuals. Like traditional [[conflict of laws]] rules, cross-border insolvency focuses upon three areas: choice of law rules, jurisdiction rules and enforcement of judgment rules.<ref>{{cite book|title=Insolvency Law|publisher=Jordans|author=Andrew Keay and Peter Walton|edition=2nd|year=2011|page=385|isbn=978-1846611193}}</ref> However, in relation to insolvency, the principal focus tends to be the recognition of foreign insolvency officials and their powers.
==Theories of cross-border insolvency== There are, broadly, three approaches to the administration of cross-border insolvency:<ref>{{cite book|title=Insolvency Law|publisher=Jordans|author=Andrew Keay and Peter Walton|edition=2nd|year=2011|page=386|isbn=978-1846611193}}</ref> * '''The territorial approach''', whereby each country exercises its own domestic insolvency laws in relation to all the debtor's property and all of the creditors located within its jurisdiction. This approach does not recognise any extraterritorial dimension to insolvency law. * '''The universalist approach''' (or ''universal approach''), whereby any cross-border insolvencies are administered pursuant to a single global insolvency regime, and all of the debtor's assets are distributed by a single insolvency office holder, regardless where the assets or claimants are located. * '''Hybrid approach'''. A number of hybrid approaches exist in theory or practice, including: ** [[Modified universalism]], whereby individual countries seek to identify the most relevant jurisdiction in which to conduct the proceedings, and all other states cooperate with and facilitate such proceedings (subject to limits of [[public policy]]);<ref>{{cite journal |author=Jay Westbrook |date= |title=Global Solution to Multinational Default |url=http://test.iiiglobal.org/downloads/Insolvency%20Topics/Sovereign%20Insolvencies/18~_Global_Solution_to_Multinational_Default.pdf |journal=[[Michigan Law Review]] |year=2000 |volume=98 |page=2276 |doi=10.2307/1290306 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150623122232/http://test.iiiglobal.org/downloads/Insolvency%20Topics/Sovereign%20Insolvencies/18~_Global_Solution_to_Multinational_Default.pdf |archivedate=23 June 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> or ** Co-operative territorialism, which is broadly predicated on territorialist approach supplemented by multi-lateral conventions.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Lynn LoPucki |date= |title=Cooperation in International Bankruptcy: A Post-Universalist Approach |url=http://www.lawschool.cornell.edu/research/cornell-law-review/upload/Lopucki.pdf |journal=[[Cornell Law Review]] |year=1999 |volume=86 |page=696 }}</ref>
The universalist approach remains largely a holistic ideal and, for the most part, countries are divided into those with a purely territorial approach, and those that apply some form of hybrid approach.
==Development==
Historically, most legal systems have developed on a territorial basis, and this is as true in relation to bankruptcy laws as other areas. However, from an early stage there have been piecemeal attempts to develop cross-border cooperation in insolvency matters.<ref>{{cite book|title=Insolvency Law|publisher=Jordans|author=Andrew Keay and Peter Walton|edition=2nd|year=2011|page=387|isbn=978-1846611193}}</ref> * In 1889 seven treaties were signed in Montevideo with the aim to harmonising [[private international law]] in the signatory states ([[Argentina]], [[Bolivia]], [[Paraguay]], [[Peru]] and [[Uruguay]]),<ref>{{cite web|jstor=742785|title=The Treaties of Montevideo (1889)|author=Wyndham Bewes|date=}}</ref> one of which related to the regulation of bankruptcies between member states. The treaty was updated in 1930, and broadly provided for a system more closer to territorialism than universality, providing for multiple bankruptcy administrations in different states for multinational companies.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com.hk/books?id=f_yWaV_-_l4C&pg=PT946&lpg=PT946&dq=Montevideo+Bankruptcy+Treaty&source=bl&ots=D-jm4fRiV6&sig=jibUcGANCJ2UJY03tYpmJyVIWFU&hl=en&sa=X&ei=CPiIVfrIO4G2-QHt6YO4Dw&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Montevideo%20Bankruptcy%20Treaty&f=false|title=Principles of International Insolvency|author=Philip Wood|publisher=[[Sweet & Maxwell]]|location=29-080| year=2007 |isbn=9781847032102 |accessdate=23 June 2015}}</ref> * In 1933 Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden signed into law the [[Nordic Bankruptcy Convention]] which, although not a lengthy document, is still in force today and facilitates administration of cross border bankruptcies in the Scandinavia region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://test.iiiglobal.org/downloads/country%20resources/Norway/Articles/1~_Nordic_Bankruptcy.pdf|title=The Nordic Bankruptcy Convention - An Introduction|author=Carl Hugo Parment|date=|accessdate=23 June 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150623141319/http://test.iiiglobal.org/downloads/country%20resources/Norway/Articles/1~_Nordic_Bankruptcy.pdf|archivedate=23 June 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * In the 1980s the [[International Bar Association]] published a model law, the Model International Insolvency Co-operation Act,<ref>{{cite journal |author=Elizabeth Somers |date= |title=The Model International Insolvency Cooperation Act: An International Proposal for Domestic Legislation |url=http://digitalcommons.wcl.american.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1571&context=auilr |journal=[[American University International Law Review]] |year=2011 |volume=6 |issue=4 |page=677 }}</ref> but ultimately this model was not adopted by any country and the attempt was unsuccessful.
But from a comparatively early stage [[common law]] jurisdictions recognised the desirability of ensuring that insolvency officers from different jurisdictions received the necessary support to enable the efficient administration of estates. Under English law one of the earliest recorded cases was ''Solomons v Ross'' (1764) 1 H Bl 131n. In that case a firm in the Netherlands was declared bankrupt and assignees were appointed. An English creditor had brought [[garnishment|garnishee proceedings]] in England to attach certain sums owing to the Dutch firm but Bathurst J held that the bankruptcy had vested all the firm's assets (including debts owed by English debtors) in the Dutch assignees, and the English creditor had to surrender the fruits of the garnishee proceedings and prove in the Dutch bankruptcy. In ''Re African Farms'' 1906 TS 373 an English company with assets in the [[Transvaal Colony]] was in [[winding-up]] in England, and the Chief Justice of the Transvaal confirmed that the English [[liquidator (law)|liquidator]] would be recognised and that "recognition which carries with it the active assistance of the court", and that active assistance could include: "A declaration, in effect, that the liquidator is entitled to deal with the Transvaal assets in the same way as if they were within the jurisdiction of the English courts, subject only to such conditions as the court may impose for the protection of local creditors, or in recognition of the requirements of our local laws." In ''Galbraith v Grimshaw'' [1910] AC 508 [[Andrew Murray, 1st Viscount Dunedin|Lord Dunedin]] stated that there should be only one universal process of the distribution of a bankrupt's property and that, where such a process was pending elsewhere, the English courts should not let actions in its jurisdiction interfere with that process.<ref>"Now so far as the general principle is concerned it is quite consistent with the comity of nations that it should be a rule of international law that if the court finds that there is already pending a process of universal distribution of a bankrupt's effects it should not allow steps to be taken in its territory which would interfere with that process of universal distribution." at 513</ref>
However, the first significant developments in relation to cross-border insolvency regimes which were widely adopted were (1) the UNCITRAL Model Law, and (2) the EC Regulation on Insolvency Proceedings 2000.
==Modern regimes==
Two current regimes for international insolvencies have been implemented on something wider than a regional basis: the UNCITRAL Model Law on Cross-Border Insolvency, and the EC Regulation on Insolvency Proceedings 2000.<ref>No 1346/2000</ref> Both regimes locate the ''centre of main interest'' (or "COMI") of the debtor.
===The UNCITRAL Model Law=== {{Main article|UNCITRAL Model Law on Cross-Border Insolvency}} The [[United Nations Commission on International Trade Law]] adopted a model law relating to cross-border insolvency on 30 June 1997.<ref name=uncitral>{{cite web|url=http://www.uncitral.org/uncitral/en/uncitral_texts/insolvency/1997Model.html|title=UNCITRAL Model Law on Cross-Border Insolvency (1997)|publisher=UNCITRAL|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref> At present 46 jurisdictions have substantially implemented the Model Law into their domestic legislation, including a number of states with both significant economies and large volumes of cross border trade—such as the United States, Japan, the United Kingdom, Australia and Canada, as well as leading emerging economies such as Mexico and [[South Africa]].
The basic concept of the Model Law is to establish what the "main proceedings" are in relation to any international insolvency. All other proceedings are referred to as the "non-main proceedings". The main proceedings are commenced where the debtor has its centre of main interest, or "COMI".<ref name=uncitral /> Non-main proceedings may be commenced in any place where the debtor has a commercial establishment. The Model Law does not require reciprocity between states, but focuses upon (i) ensuring that states give assistance to insolvency officials from other countries in relation to main proceedings and non-main proceedings, and (ii) eliminating preferences for local creditors over international ones.<ref>Model Law, Article 13, paragraph 2</ref>
The following countries have substantially implemented the Model Law into their domestic legislation.<ref name=Countries>{{cite web|url=http://www.uncitral.org/uncitral/en/uncitral_texts/insolvency/1997Model_status.html|title=Status - UNCITRAL Model Law on Cross-Border Insolvency (1997)|publisher=UNCITRAL|accessdate=21 June 2018}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! State ! Date of Ratification ! State ! Date of Ratification |- | {{flag|Australia}} || 2008 || {{flag|Benin}} || 2015 |- | {{flag|British Virgin Islands}} || 2003<ref>Although the British Virgin Islands has enacted provisions of the Model Law as Part XVIII of the Insolvency Act, 2003 (which came into force on 1 January 2004), that Part has not yet been brought into force. See generally: [[British Virgin Islands bankruptcy law#Cross-border insolvency|British Virgin Islands bankruptcy law]].</ref> || {{flag|Burkina Faso}} || 2015 |- | {{flag|Cameroon}} || 2015 || {{flag|Canada}} || 2005 |- | {{flag|Central African Republic}} || 2015 || {{flag|Chad}} || 2015 |- | {{flag|Chile}} || 2013 || {{flag|Colombia}} || 2006 |- | {{flag|Comoros}} || 2015 || {{flag|Congo}} || 2015 |- | {{flag|Côte d'Ivoire}} || 2015 || {{flag|Democratic Republic of the Congo}} || 2015 |- | {{flag|Equatorial Guinea}} || 2015 || {{flag|Gabon}} || 2015 |- | {{flag|Gibraltar}} || 2014 || {{flag|Greece}} || 2010 |- | {{flag|Guinea}} || 2015 || {{flag|Guinea-Bissau}} || 2015 |- | {{flag|Israel}} || 2018 || {{flag|Japan}} || 2000 |- | {{flag|Kenya}} || 2015 || {{flag|Malawi}} || 2015 |- | {{flag|Mali}} || 2015 || {{flag|Mauritius}} || 2009 |- | {{flag|Mexico}} || 2000 || {{flag|Montenegro}} || 2002 |- | {{flag|New Zealand}} || 2006 || {{flag|Niger}} || 2015 |- | {{flag|Philippines}} || 2010 || {{flag|Poland}} || 2003 |- | {{flag|Republic of Korea}} || 2006 || {{flag|Romania}} || 2002 |- | {{flag|Senegal}} || 2015 || {{flag|Serbia}} || 2004 |- | {{flag|Seychelles}} || 2013 || {{flag|Singapore}} || 2017 |- | {{flag|Slovenia}} || 2007 || {{flag|South Africa}} || 2000 |- | {{flag|Togo}} || 2015 || {{flag|Uganda}} || 2011 |- | {{flag|United Kingdom}} || 2006<ref>See [[United Kingdom insolvency law#International insolvency|United Kingdom insolvency law - International insolvency]]</ref> || {{flag|United States}} || 2005<ref>See [[Chapter 15, Title 11, United States Code]].</ref> |- | {{flag|Vanuatu}} || 2013 || || |}
===EC Regulation on Insolvency Proceedings 2000===
{{Main article|Insolvency Regulation (EC) 1346/2000}}
The [[Regulation (European Union)|EC Regulation]] on Insolvency Proceedings 2000 was passed on 29 May 2000 and came into effect on 31 May 2002.<ref name=ECReg>{{cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/en/TXT/?uri=CELEX:32000R1346|title=Council regulation (EC) No 1346/2000 of 29 May 2000 on insolvency proceedings|publisher=Eur-Lex|date=|accessdate=23 June 2015}}</ref> The EC Regulation, as its name applies, operates between member states of the [[European Union]], and focuses upon creating a framework for the commencement of proceedings and for the automatic recognition and co-operation between the different member states. Unusually for a European regulation, the EC Insolvency Regulation does not seek to harmonise insolvency laws between the different member states.
Like the UNCITRAL Model Law, the EC Regulation also employs the concept of a centre of main interest (or "COMI"). The definition of the COMI is left to member states in their implementation of the Regulation, but paragraph (13) of the preamble states: 'The "centre of main interests" should correspond to the place where the debtor conducts the administration of his interests on a regular basis and is therefore ascertainable by third parties.' If the COMI of an entity is outside of the European Union then the insolvency proceedings are not subject to the Regulation.<ref>''Re the Arena Corporation Ltd'' [2003] EWHC 3032 (Ch.), affirmed on appeal ([2004] EWCA Civ 371).</ref> In relation to [[corporation|companies]] there is a [[presumption (law)|presumption]] that the registered office is the COMI of the company, but this presumption can be (and often is) [[rebuttal|rebutted]].<ref>''Re AIM Underwriting Agencies'' [2004] EWHC Civ 2114; ''Re TXU Europe German Finance BV'' [2005] BCC 90.</ref>
The EC Regulation does not define insolvency, but it does define insolvency proceedings as "...collective insolvency proceedings which entail the partial or total divestment of a debtor and the appointment of a liquidator."<ref>Article 1(1).</ref> Article 3 divides proceedings into main proceedings and territorial proceedings. Main proceedings are accorded extraterritorial effect throughout the European Union. One of the concerns expressed in relation to the EC Regulation is that (other than a reference to the [[European Court of Justice]]) it provides no mechanism for determining which set of proceedings are the main proceedings if two or more jurisdictions claim their proceedings are the main proceedings.<ref>''Re Eurofood IFSC Ltd'' (Case C-341/04), [2006] ECR 1-701</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Insolvency Law|publisher=Jordans|author=Andrew Keay and Peter Walton|edition=2nd|year=2011|page=400|isbn=978-1846611193}}</ref>
==Areas of conflict==
In any attempt to harmonise or facilitate cross-border administration of insolvent companies, national insolvency regimes can take widely divergent approaches on certain key points:
* '''[[Secured creditor]]s.''' Whether or not bankruptcy proceedings operate as a stay upon the enforcement of secured creditor's rights as a fundamental determinant in relation to the manner of conduct of any proceedings * '''Corporate rehabilitation regimes.''' Bankruptcy systems predicated on trying to rehabilitate companies (such as [[Chapter 11]] in the United States, or [[administration order]]s in the United Kingdom) are fundamentally different in intent and effect to winding-up regimes that seeks to liquidate companies and distribute the proceeds to creditors. * '''Set-off rights.''' Whilst certain countries allow creditors who have mutual claims with the debtor to [[set-off (law)|set-off]] those claims in full, others require the creditors to pay any sums owed to the debtor in full before claiming in the proceedings. Within jurisdictions that do permit set-off, variations may arise as to whether set-off must be on an individual or group basis.<ref>In an insolvent liquidation, banks who provide loan finance are often key creditors. Similarly, most companies also have cash-at-bank as one of their assets. The ability of banks to set-off those sums can be a material factor.</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
[[Category:Bankruptcy]] [[Category:Cross-border insolvency| ]] [[Category:Conflict of laws]]

'''Customer analytics''' is a process by which data from [[customer behavior]] is used to help make key business [[decision support system|decisions]] via [[market segment]]ation and [[predictive analytics]]. This information is used by businesses for [[direct marketing]], [[site selection]], and [[customer relationship management]]. Marketing provides services in order to satisfy customers. With that in mind, the productive system is considered from its beginning at the production level, to the end of the cycle at the consumer. Customer analytics plays an important role in the prediction of customer behavior.<ref>Kioumarsi et al., 2009</ref>
==Uses== ;Retail:Although until recently over 90% of retailers had limited visibility on their customers<ref>{{cite web |title=The futre of retail supply chains |url=https://www.mckinsey.com/~/media/mckinsey/dotcom/client_service/retail/articles/future_of_retail_supply_chains.ashx |website=www.mckinsey.com |accessdate=22 November 2018}}</ref>, with increasing investments in loyalty programs, customer tracking solutions and market research, this industry started increasing use of customer analytics in decisions ranging from product, promotion, price and distribution management.{{cn|date=May 2016}} The most obvious use of customer analytics in retail today is the development of personalized communications and offers and/or different marketing programs by segment.{{cn|date=May 2016}} Additional reasons set forth by Bain & Co. include: prioritizing product development efforts, designing distribution strategies and determining product pricing.<ref>Bain & Co.{{clarify|research paper? publication?|date=May 2016}}</ref> Demographic, lifestyle, preference, loyalty data, behavior, shopper value and predictive behavior data points are key to the success of customer analytics.{{cn|date=May 2016}} ;Finance: Banks, insurance companies and pension funds make use of customer analytics in understanding customer lifetime value, identifying below-zero customers which are estimated to be around 30% of customer base, increasing cross-sales, managing [[customer attrition]] as well as migrating customers to lower cost channels in a targeted manner. ;Community: Municipalities utilize customer analytics in an effort to lure retailers to their cities. Using [[psychographic]] variables, communities can be segmented based on attributes like personality, values, interests, and lifestyle. Using this information, communities can approach retailers that match their community’s profile. ;Customer relationship management: Analytical [[Customer Relationship Management]], commonly abbreviated as CRM, enables measurement of and prediction from customer data to provide a 360° view of the client.
==Predicting customer behaviour== Forecasting [[Consumer behaviour|buying habits]] and [[lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]] preferences is a process of data mining and analysis. This information consists of many aspects like [[credit card]] purchases, [[magazine subscription]]s, [[loyalty card]] membership, [[survey (human research)|surveys]], and [[voter registration]]. Using these categories, [[consumer profile]]s can be created for any organization’s most profitable customers. When many of these potential customers are aggregated in a single area it indicates a fertile location for the business to situate. Using a drive time analysis, it is also possible to predict how far a given customer will drive to a particular location. Combining these sources of information, a dollar value can be placed on each household within a trade area detailing the likelihood that household will be worth to a company. Through customer analytics, companies can make decisions based on facts and objective data.
===Data mining=== There are two types of categories of [[data mining]]. [[Predictive model]]s use previous customer interactions to predict future events while [[data clustering|segmentation techniques]] are used to place customers with similar behaviors and attributes into distinct groups. This grouping can help marketers to optimize their campaign management and targeting processes.
==See also== * [[Buyer decision processes]] * [[Business analytics]] * [[Customer interaction tracker]] * [[Data warehouse]] * [[Psychographics]] * [[Mattersight Corporation]] * [[Customer privacy]] * [[Customer data management]]

{{Distinguish|American Eagle Tankers}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Use British English|date=July 2017}} '''Eagle Oil and Shipping Company''' was a [[United Kingdom]] merchant shipping company that operated [[Tanker (ship)|oil tankers]] between the [[Gulf of Mexico]] and the UK. [[Weetman Pearson, 1st Viscount Cowdray]] founded it as the '''Eagle Oil Transport Company''' in 1912 and sold it to [[Royal Dutch Shell]] in 1919. It was renamed Eagle Oil and Shipping Company in about 1930, and remained a separate company within the Royal Dutch Shell group until it was absorbed in 1959.
==Pearson oil interests in Mexico== [[File:1st Viscount Cowdray.jpg|thumb|Weetman Pearson, Viscount Cowdray]] Sir Weetman Pearson, [[Baronet|Bart.]] (ennobled as [[Viscount Cowdray]] in 1910) headed a successful civil engineering contractor, [[Pearson PLC|S. Pearson and Sons]], that had contracts in Mexico from 1889. He initiated oil prospecting there in 1901 and founded the [[Mexican Eagle Petroleum Company]] in 1909, which had its first major oil strike in 1910 (near [[Tampico, Tamaulipas|Tampico]] on the [[Gulf of Mexico]] coast).
Before Pearson struck oil, he started to order [[History of the oil tanker#Breaking the Standard Oil monopoly|oil tankers]] to carry the oil that he hoped to produce. [[Armstrong Whitworth]] on the [[River Tyne]] launched ''San Cristobal'' (2,041 tons) in 1906 and [[Swan Hunter]], also on Tyneside, launched ''San Antonio'' (5,251 tons) in 1909. Pearson also bought ''James Brand'' (3,907 tons), which had been built by Armstrong Whitworth in 1893, and renamed her ''San Bernardo''.
==Eagle Oil Transport Company== In 1912 Pearson founded the Eagle Oil Transport Company in the UK to take over his ships and carry Mexican Eagle's products.<ref>{{cite news |author= [[Marconi Company|Marconi Transatlantic Wireless Telegraph]] |date=1912-02-29 |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |title= Form $5,000,000 Line.; Cowdray Interests to Build Fleet to Carry Mexican Oil Products |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B0CE1DB123BE633A2575AC2A9649C946396D6CF |accessdate=}}</ref> He also founded the '''Anglo-Mexican Petroleum Company''' in the UK to sell Mexican Eagle's products outside Mexico.{{sfn|Godley|2007|pp=15, 16}}
Eagle Oil Transport immediately ordered 20 modern steam tankers{{sfn|Godley|2007|p=15}} at a cost of [[Pound sterling|£]]3 million.{{sfn|Godley|2007|p=18}} The company gave all the ships the Spanish names of [[Christianity|Christian]] [[saint]]s, most of them ending in ''"o"''.{{sfn|Talbot-Booth|1942|p=460}} Swan Hunter launched {{SS|San Dunstano||2}} (6,238 tons)<ref name=WreckSiteDunstano>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?113247 |title=SS San Dunstano [+1929] |last1=Lettens |first1=Jan |last2=Allen |first2=Tony |date=2011-10-13 |work=The Wreck Site |publisher= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref> and {{SS|San Eduardo||2}} (6,225 tons) in 1912,<ref name=Lloyds1930>{{cite book |title=Lloyd's Register of Shipping |year=1930 |publisher=[[Lloyd's of London]] |location=London |page= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref> {{SS|San Fraterno||2}} (11,929 tons)<ref name=WreckSiteFraterno>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?136089 |title=SS San Fraterno [+1927] |last=Allen |first=Tony |date=2011-01-06 |work=The Wreck Site |publisher= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref> ''San Silvestre'' (6,223 tons), ''San Tirso'' (6,236 tons) and ''San Gregorio'' (12,093 tons) in 1913 and ''San Lorenzo'' (12,097 tons) in 1914. [[Palmers Shipbuilding and Iron Company]], also on the Tyne, launched {{SS|San Hilario||2}} (10,157 tons) and ''San Valerio'' (6,493 tons) in 1913 and {{SS|San Melito||2}} (12,286 tons) in 1914.<ref name=Lloyds1930/> [[William Doxford & Sons]] launched [[SS Southern Empress|''San Jeronimo'']] (12,398 tons), ''San Nazario'' (12,029 tons) and ''San Zeferino'' (6,433 tons) in 1914. Armstrong Whitworth launched ''San Ricardo'' (6,465 tons) and {{SS|San Urbano||2}} (6,458 tons) in 1913, {{SS|San Wilfrido|1914|2}} (6,458 tons), [[SS Dordogne|''San Isidoro'']] (9,718 tons) and {{SS|San Onofre||2}} (9,717 tons) in 1914 and [[SS Southern Princess|''San Patricio'']] (12,092 tons) in 1915.<ref name=Lloyds1930/>
Eagle Oil Transport suffered significant war losses in the First World War. On 3 August 1914 ''San Wilfrido'' struck a [[Naval mine|mine]] and sank off Cuxhaven in the North Sea, making her the first merchant ship sunk in the [[World War I|First World War]]. German submarines torpedoed and sank ''San Hilario'' in April 1917 and ''San Urbano'' and ''San Onofre'' in May 1917, all in the [[North Atlantic]] to the west of Ireland. In 1915 the company had bought a [[Cargo ship|dry cargo]] [[steamship]], ''Drumlanrig'', which was renamed {{SS|Santa Amalia||2}}.<ref name=WreckSiteAmalia>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?63352 |title=SS Santa Amalia [+1917] |last=Lettens |first=Jan |date=2011-09-19 |work=The Wreck Site |publisher= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref> In December 1917 the German submarine {{SMU|U-19|Germany|6}} torpedoed and sank ''Santa Amalia'' in the North Atlantic to the west of [[Islay]], with the loss of 43 officers and crew.<ref name=WreckSiteAmalia/> ''San Zeferino'' was damaged by enemy action during the war.
Eagle Oil Transport had at least one motor tanker by the end of the War; the {{MV|San Dario||2}} (1,137 tons), which had been launched in 1918 by [[Short Brothers of Sunderland]].<ref name=Lloyds1930/> The company continued to buy new steam tankers until at least 1928, when [[J.L. Thompson and Sons]] launched SS ''San Casto'' (2,446 tons) on the [[River Wear]] and Armstrong Whitworth launched SS ''San Claudio'' (2,712 tons).<ref name=Lloyds1930/>
In 1919 Viscount Cowdray sold his group of oil companies to [[Royal Dutch Shell]].{{sfn|Godley|2007|p=1}} Eagle Oil Transport renewed and expanded its fleet, and some of the new ships were very large by the standards of the day. Armstrong Whitworth launched {{SS|San Fernando||2}} (13,056 tons) in 1919, ''San Felix'' (13,037 tons) in 1921 and {{SS|San Fabian||2}} (13,013 tons) in 1922.<ref name=Lloyds1930/> Swan Hunter launched {{SS|San Florentino||2}} (12,842 tons) in 1919 and Palmers launched ''San Gaspar'' (12,910 tons) in 1921 and {{SS|San Gerardo||2}} (12,915 tons) in 1922.<ref name=Lloyds1930/>
Eagle Oil also bought new medium-sized tankers. Swan Hunter built the War Standard tanker ''War Kookri'' (5,582 tons) for the War Shipping Controller, but when she was launched in 1919 Cowdray bought her and renamed her ''San Zotico''.<ref name=Lloyds1930/> Cowdray then turned to the USA for new ships of this size. Standard Shipbuilding Company of [[Shooters Island#Shipyard|Shooters Island]], New York launched ''San Teodoro'' (6,137 tons), {{SS|San Tiburcio||2}} (5,995 tons)<ref name=WreckSiteTiburcio>{{cite web |url= http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?10342 |title=MV San Tiburcio [+1940] |last1=Lettens |first1=Jan |last2=Vleggeert |first2=Nico |date=2010-01-06 |work=The Wreck Site |publisher= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref> and ''San Ubaldo'' (5,999 tons) in 1921.<ref name=Lloyds1930/>
After 1921 Cowdray reverted to UK shipyards. Armstrong Whitworth launched ''San Roberto'' (5,890 tons) and ''San Rosendo'' (5,891 tons) in 1922, ''San Quirino'' (5,843 tons) in 1923 and ''San Salvador'' (5,805 tons) in 1924.<ref name=Lloyds1930/>
In 1927 ''San Fraterno'' was wrecked on a rock at Bonet Island in the [[Strait of Magellan]]<ref name=WreckSiteFraterno/> and in 1929 ''San Dunstano'' was wrecked at the entrance to Tampico harbour.<ref name=WreckSiteDunstano/>
In about 1930 the Eagle Oil Transport Company was renamed the Eagle Oil and Shipping Company.<ref name=Lloyds1930/> In about 1935 the company started adding a new generation of motor tankers including ''San Adolfo'' (7,365 tons) launched by the [[Furness Shipbuilding Company]] on the [[River Tees]], {{MV|San Alberto||2}} (7,397 tons) launched by [[Lithgows]] on the [[River Clyde]], {{MV|San Alvaro||2}} (7,385 tons) launched by Swan Hunter, ''San Amado'' (7,316 tons) launched by the Blythswood Shipbuilding Company on the Clyde, ''San Ambrosio'' (7,410 tons) launched by [[Hawthorn Leslie and Company#Shipbuilding|Hawthorn Leslie and Company]] on the Tyne and {{MV|San Arcadio||2}} (7,419 tons) launched by [[Harland and Wolff]] in [[Belfast]], Northern Ireland.<ref name=Lloyds1935>{{cite book |title=Lloyd's Register of Shipping |year=1935 |publisher=[[Lloyd's of London]] |location=London |page= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref> New additions continued until 1939, when Lithgows launched MV ''San Eliseo'' (8,042 tons), Harland and Wolff launched {{MV|San Emiliano||2}} (8,071 tons) and Furness Shipbuilding launched {{MV|San Ernesto||2}} (8,078 tons).<ref name=Lloyds1940>{{cite book |title=Lloyd's Register of Shipping |year=1940 |publisher=[[Lloyd's of London]] |location=London |page= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref>
Eagle Oil and Shipping was registered in the United Kingdom. Therefore, after 1938 although the Mexican government had nationalised Mexican Eagle Petroleum, Eagle Oil and Shipping remained a subsidiary of Royal Dutch Shell. After 1938 the fleet continued to carry oil from the [[Gulf of Mexico]] to the UK.{{sfn|Talbot-Booth|1942|p=461}} During the [[World War II|Second World War]] the company played an important role in supplying petroleum and petroleum products to the United Kingdom. Oil tankers were a particular target in Germany's economic warfare against the Allies. Enemy action sank 17 Eagle Oil ships, killing at least 206 officers, men and [[Defensively Equipped Merchant Ships#World War II|DEMS]] gunners.
{{MV|San Calisto||2}} (8,018 tons) was launched by Lithgows on the Clyde in 1937.<ref name=WreckSiteCalisto>{{cite web |url= http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?73908 |title=MV San Calisto [+1939] |last1=Lettens |first1=Jan |last2=Vleggeert |first2=Nico |date=2010-01-06 |work=The Wreck Site |publisher= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref> On 2 December 1939 she struck a mine off the [[Tongue Lightship]] in the [[Thames Estuary]] and sank with the loss of six men.<ref name=WreckSiteCalisto/> On 4 May 1940 ''San Tiburcio'' struck a mine and sank in the [[North Sea]] off the [[Moray Firth]].<ref name=WreckSiteTiburcio/>
{{MV|San Casimiro||2}} (8,045 tons) and {{MV|San Conrado||2}} (7,982 tons) were sister ships launched by Blythswood at [[Scotstoun]] in 1936. ''San Casimiro'' was captured off [[Cape Race]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]] by the German battleship ''[[German battleship Gneisenau|Gneisenau]]'' on 15 March 1941 and scuttled off the [[Azores]] five days later.<ref name=WreckSiteCasimiro>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?31291 |title=MV San Casimiro [+1941] |last1=Allen |first1=Tony |last2=Vleggeert |first2=Nico |date=2010-01-06 |work=The Wreck Site |publisher= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref> ''San Conrado'' was bombed and sunk by enemy aircraft off [[Smalls Lighthouse|The Smalls]] on the coast of west [[Wales]] on 1 April 1941.<ref name=WreckSiteConrado>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?59067 |title=MV San Conrado [+1941] |last1=Allen |first1=Tony |last2=Vleggeert |first2=Nico |date=2010-01-06 |work=The Wreck Site |publisher= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref>
[[File:MT SAN DEMETRIO.jpg|thumb|300px|{{MV|San Demetrio||2}} reached the Clyde in 1940 carrying a cargo of aviation spirit, despite having been damaged and set on fire by shelling from the ''[[German cruiser Admiral Scheer|Admiral Scheer]]'']] {{MV|San Demetrio||2}} (8,073 tons), which Blythswood had launched at [[Port Glasgow]] in 1938, became famous for surviving a naval bombardment by the German [[heavy cruiser]] ''[[German cruiser Admiral Scheer|Admiral Scheer]]'' in 1940. ''San Demetrio''{{'}}s crew succeeded in extinguishing the resultant fire and bringing the ship and her cargo of aviation spirit to [[Glasgow]], Scotland. ''San Demetrio'' was repaired and returned to service, but the {{GS|U-404}} torpedoed and sank her in the western Atlantic off [[Virginia]] on 17 March 1942 with the loss of 19 lives.
On 2 October 1941 the {{GS|U-98|1940|2}} torpedoed and sank ''San Florentino'' north of the Azores with the loss of 22 lives.<ref name=WreckSiteFlorentino>{{cite web |url= http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?15167 |title= SS San Florentino [+1941] |last1=Allen |first1=Tony |last2=Vleggeert |first2=Nico |date=2011-01-06 |work=The Wreck Site |publisher= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref> On 31 March 1942 {{GS|U-71|1940|2}} torpedoed and sank SS ''San Gerardo'' off the eastern coast of the USA with the loss of 51 lives.<ref name=WreckSiteGerardo>{{cite web |url= http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?136090 |title= SS San Gerardo [+1942] |last1=Allen |first1=Tony |last2=Vleggeert |first2=Nico |date=2011-01-06 |work=The Wreck Site |publisher= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref> On 9 April 1942 {{GS|U-203||2}} torpedoed and sank {{MV|San Delfino||2}} (8,072 tons) in the North Atlantic off Cape Hatteras, USA with the loss of 28 lives.<ref name=WreckSiteDelfino>{{cite web |url= http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?15452 |title=MV San Delfino [+1942] |last1=Claes |first1=Johnny |last2=Vleggeert |first2=Nico |date=2010-12-08 |work=The Wreck Site |publisher= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref> On 17 May 1942 {{GS|U-155|1941|2}} torpedoed and sank ''San Demetrio''{{'}}s sister ship {{MV|San Victorio||2}} in the eastern Caribbean southwest of [[Grenada]] with the loss of 52 lives.<ref name=WreckSiteVictorio>{{cite web |url= http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?58069|title=MV San Victorio [+1942] |last1=Claes |first1=Johnny |last2=Lettens |first2=Jan |date=2011-01-06 |work=The Wreck Site |publisher= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref> On 27 August 1942 {{GS|U-511||2}} torpedoed and sank SS ''San Fabian'' between [[Jamaica]] and the [[Dominican Republic]] in the [[Caribbean]] with the loss of 26 lives.<ref name=WreckSiteFabian>{{cite web |url= http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?17610 |title= SS San Fabian [+1942] |last1=Allen |first1=Tony |last2=Vleggeert |first2=Nico |date=2011-01-06 |work=The Wreck Site |publisher= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref>
[[File:StateLibQld 1 172031 San Ernesco (ship).jpg|thumb|300px|The Japanese submarine {{ship|Japanese submarine|I-37||2}} torpedoed {{MV|San Ernesto||2}} in the Indian Ocean in 1943. The crew abandoned ship but the tanker stayed afloat and drifted 2,000 miles to [[Nias]] in the [[Dutch East Indies]], where occupying Japanese forces dismantled her.]] In 1942 the [[Ministry of War Transport]] placed the [[Empire ship#Tankers|Empire ships]] {{SS|Empire Airman|1941|2}}, {{SS|Empire Cobbett||2}} and {{SS|Empire Norseman||2}}<ref name=WreckSiteNorseman>{{cite web |url= http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?30614 |title=SS Empire Norseman [+1943] |last1=Claes |first1=Johnny |last2=Vleggeert |first2=Nico |date=2010-01-23 |work=The Wreck Site |publisher= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref> under Eagle Oil and Shipping's management. In 1943 two U-boats torpedoed and sank ''Empire Norseman'' (9,811 tons) in the Atlantic south of the Azores. After the Second World War the company bought ''Empire Airman'' and ''Empire Cobbett'' from the ministry, renamed them ''San Wenceslao'' and ''San Wilfrido'' respectively and kept them in service until 1959.
During the war Eagle Oil and Shipping bought several new tankers to replace war losses. Harland and Wolff launched ''San Veronico'' (8,198 tons) and ''San Vulframo'' (8,167 tons) in 1942 and ''San Vito'' (8,163 tons) in 1943.<ref name=Lloyds1945>{{cite book |title=Lloyd's Register of Shipping |year=1945 |publisher=[[Lloyd's of London]] |location=London |page= |accessdate=2011-11-21}}</ref> Hawthorn Leslie launched ''San Venancio'' (8,152 tons) in 1942 and ''San Velino'' (8,210 tons) in 1944.<ref name=Lloyds1945/> After the War, Eagle Oil bought two US-built [[T2 tanker]]s: ''Bryce Canyon'' in 1948 and ''Laurel Hill'' in 1949. The company renamed them ''San Leonardo'' and ''San Leopoldo'' respectively and kept them in service until 1961.
Between 1950 and 1960 Eagle Oil acquired at least 16 new tankers. Two of the earliest were a second ''San Salvador'' (10,802 tons) and a second ''San Silvestre'' (10,953 tons), both launched by Furness Shipbuilding in 1950. Later ships included {{SS|San Flaviano||2}} (12,278 tons)<ref name=WreckSiteFlaviano>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?108400 |title=SS San Flaviano [+1958] |last=Lettens |first=Jan |date=2011-01-06 |work=The Wreck Site |publisher= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}</ref> and SS ''San Fortunato'' (12,257 tons), both launched in 1956 by [[Cammell Laird]] on the [[River Mersey]].
In April 1958 a [[Douglas A-26 Invader|Douglas B-26 Invader]] bomber aircraft, painted black and with no markings,{{sfn|Conboy|Morrison|1999|p=88}} bombed and sank ''San Flaviano'' in [[Balikpapan]] Harbour, [[Borneo]], killing two of her crew.<ref name=WreckSiteFlaviano/>{{sfn|Conboy|Morrison|1999|p=116}}<ref name=Hansard>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction=United Kingdom |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1958/jun/11/indonesia-british-vessels#S5CV0589P0_19580611_HOC_160 |title=Indonesia (British Vessels) |house=Commons |date=1958-06-11 |column_start=202 |column_end=203 |speaker= [[David Ormsby-Gore, 5th Baron Harlech|David Ormsby-Gore]] |position=Minister of State for Foreign Affairs |accessdate=2011-11-21}}</ref><ref name=Time>{{cite news|title=INDONESIA: The Mystery Pilots |newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |url=http://search.time.com/results.html?N=55&Nty=1&Ns=p_date_range%7C1&Ntt=San+Flaviano&from_month=03&from_day=01&from_year=1958&to_month=06&to_day=01&to_year=1958&x=45&y=14 |date=1958-05-12 |accessdate=2011-11-21 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The aircraft, its bombs and its pilot, [[William H. Beale]], were sent by the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] as part of US covert support for the [[Permesta]] rebellion in [[North Sulawesi]].{{sfn|Conboy|Morrison|1999|pp=99–100}} UK Prime Minister [[Harold Macmillan]] and Foreign Secretary [[Selwyn Lloyd]] supported the US policy to supply [[Permesta]]{{sfn|Kahin|Kahin|1997|p=156}} and on 6 May 1958, more than a week after the CIA sank ''San Flaviano'', Lloyd secretly told US Secretary of State [[John Foster Dulles]] that this was still his position.{{sfn|Kahin|Kahin|1997|p=175}} On 18 May, Indonesian forces shot down a different Permesta B-26 and captured its CIA pilot, [[Allen Lawrence Pope|Allen Pope]].{{sfn|Conboy|Morrison|1999|pp=138, 139, 141}}{{sfn|Kahin|Kahin|1997|p=179}} Nevertheless, in June 1958 both Indonesia and the UK publicly claimed that the aircraft had been flown by [[Guided Democracy in Indonesia#Regional rebellions|Indonesian rebels]],<ref name=Hansard/> concealing the CIA involvement of which both governments were well aware. The CIA pilots had orders to target commercial shipping in order to frighten foreign merchant ships away from Indonesian waters, thereby weakening the Indonesian economy and destabilising the Indonesian government of President [[Sukarno]].{{sfn|Conboy|Morrison|1999|p=116}} In this they were at least partly successful: Royal Dutch Shell suspended its tanker service to Balikpapan and evacuated shore-based wives and families to [[Singapore]].<ref name=Hansard/>
Several new ships delivered to Eagle Oil in the later 1950s were in the order of 18,000 to 19,500 tons. One of the last new ships to be delivered for the fleet was also one of the largest; the second {{MV|San Conrado|1960|2}} (34,750 tons), launched by Furness Shipbuilding in 1960. By then Royal Dutch Shell had absorbed Eagle Oil and Shipping, which ceased to be a separate member of the group in 1959.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==Sources== *{{cite book |last1=Conboy |first1=Kenneth |last2=Morrison |first2=James |year=1999 |title=Feet to the Fire CIA Covert Operations in Indonesia, 1957–1958 |location=Annapolis |publisher=[[United States Naval Institute|Naval Institute Press]] |isbn=1-55750-193-9 |pages= |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Godley |first=Andrew |title=Weetman Pearson in Mexico and the emergence of a British oil major 1900–1919 |year=2007 |publisher= [[Henley Business School|Henley School of Management]] |location=Reading, Berkshire |url= |accessdate=2011-11-20 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last1=Kahin |first1=Audrey R |last2=Kahin |first2=George McT |authorlink2=George Kahin |title=Subversion as Foreign Policy The Secret Eisenhower and Dulles Debacle in Indonesia |origyear=1995 |year=1997 |location=Seattle and London |publisher=[[University of Washington Press]] |isbn=0-295-97618-7 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Talbot-Booth |first=E.C. |origyear=1936 |year=1942 |title=Ships and the Sea |edition=Seventh |location=London |publisher=[[Sampson Low]], Marston & Co. Ltd |ref=harv}}

{{Use American English|date=July 2017}} {{BLP sources|reason=too many primary sources, blogs, and press releases|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = Ehsanollah Bayat |image = |caption = Ehsanollah in 2014 |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1963|7|15}} |birth_place = [[Ghazni Province]], [[Afghanistan]] |residence = [[Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida]] |citizenship = American |occupation = [[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]] of the [http://www.bayat-group.com Bayat Group] |website = {{official website|http://ehsanbayat.com/}} |religion = |alma mater = [[ New Jersey Institute of Technology]] }} '''Ehsanollah''' "'''Ehsan'''" '''Bayat''' ([[Persian language|Persian]]: احسان الله بیات, born July 15, 1963) is an [[Afghan American]] [[business]] [[entrepreneur]] residing in [[Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida]], United States.<ref name="PonteVedraBeach">{{cite news | title=Ponte Vedra Beach couple aid the poor of Afghanistan | work=Jacksonville.com | date=September 17, 2012 |url=http://jacksonville.com/community/shorelines/2012-09-17/story/ponte-vedra-beach-couple-aid-poor-afghanistan}}</ref>
==Early life and education== He is originally from [[Ghazni]]. He is an ethnic [[Turkmens|Turkmen]] from the Bayat tribe, and his family belongs to the [[Qizilbash]] community of [[Afghanistan]].
Ehsan Bayat grew up in Kabul's [[Kārte Seh]] district and he attended Isteqlal Primary and High School. During the 1979<ref>{{cite web | last = Herold | first = Mark W. | title = Karzai & Associates' Trickle-Down Reconstruction | publisher = Cursor | date = 2002-05-12 | url = http://www.cursor.org/stories/karzai.htm | accessdate =2008-01-20 }}</ref> Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, Ehsan Bayat and his immediate family emigrated from Afghanistan, and settled in Flushing, New York From 1982-1986 Ehsan Bayat attended The [[ New Jersey Institute of Technology]], where he earned a [[Bachelor's degree]] in [[Engineering]]. After graduating from NJIT, Mr. Bayat embarked upon an entrepreneurial career, founding successful import/export and wholesale food distribution companies.
==Career== Ehsan Bayat is the Founder and Chairman of The Bayat Group,<ref name="The Bayat Group">{{cite web | title=Official Website of The Bayat Group | publisher=bayat-group.com | date=2017-07-30 |url=http://bayat-group.com}}</ref> Afghanistan's largest diversified services company. The Bayat Group's operations in [[Afghanistan]] include three enterprises:
*[[Afghan Wireless Communication Company]] (AWCC), which serves approximately 5,000,000 subscribers throughout Afghanistan. AWCC was Afghanistan's first wireless company and established Afghanistan's wireless telecommunications sector.
*[[Ariana Television Network]] is Afghanistan's largest private media organization, broadcasting to all 34 provinces and reaching an audience of approximately 25,000,000 Afghans.
*Bayat Energy<ref name="The Bayat Energy">{{cite web | title=Official Website of The Bayat Energy | publisher=bayat-energy.com | date=2017-07-30 |url=http://bayat-energy.com}}</ref>, an oil and gas exploration, development and production company. In October 2016<ref name="Bayat Power">{{cite news | title=Bayat Power Announces Three-Phase US$250M Investment Program To Accelerate Afghanistan's Gas-Fired Power Industry | work=Prnewswire.com | date=2016-10-03 |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/bayat-power-announces-three-phase-us250m-investment-program-to-accelerate-afghanistans-gas-fired-power-industry-300337924.html}}</ref>, Bayat Power, a division of Bayat Energy, signed an agreement with the Government of Afghanistan to build Bayat-1, a Gas Fired Power plant, located in Sheberghan, Jawzjan Province. When all three phases of Bayat-1 are completed, the power plant will be capable of generating 200 Megawatts of electricity, sufficient power for approximately 200,000 homes and businesses. In 2018, Bayat Power also signed a power purchase agreement (PPA) to sell 40MW of energy generated from the new plant to the Government of Afghanistan.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bayat Power to build power plant in Afghanistan|url=https://www.power-technology.com/news/bayat-power-build-power-plant-afghanistan/|publisher=Power Technology|date=April 4, 2018}}</ref>
In addition to these three enterprises, The Bayat Group also owns companies operating within the Construction, Security, Logistics and Consumer Goods sectors.
===As founder=== After graduating college, Ehsan Bayat maintained strong ties with family and friends living in [[Afghanistan]], and among the Afghan Diaspora living in [[Pakistan]], the United States and throughout the world. Committed to rebuilding [[Afghanistan]], Ehsan Bayat returned to [[Afghanistan]] in early 2002, shortly after the fall of Afghanistan's [[Taliban]] Government in November, 2001.
When Ehsan Bayat returned to Afghanistan in early 2002, decades of armed conflict had devastated the Afghan people and destroyed Afghanistan's economy. Ehsan Bayat, using his exceptional and unique experience as an Afghan American entrepreneur who had established highly successful companies in the United States, began immediately to plan the creation of a new generation of Afghan companies which would operate, based on the following principles:
* Each company would make a positive and long-term impact on the lives of ordinary [[Afghan]].
* Each company would be run by [[Afghan]], employ Afghans, contribute to building democracy in [[Afghanistan]] and help establish positive relations between Afghanistan and the wider world.
In 2002, Ehsan Bayat founded [[Afghan Wireless Communication Company]] (AWCC). The company operates in all 34 provinces of Afghanistan, providing over 5,000,000 Afghan businesses and consumers with the world-class, high speed communications infrastructure, enabling Afghans to connect with the world.
Building on the success of Afghan Wireless, in 2005, Ehsan Bayat founded [[Ariana Television Network]]. ATN is Afghanistan's largest privately-owned media network, reaching an estimated audience of approximately 25,000,000 Afghans.
[[Afghan Wireless Communication Company]] and [[Ariana Television Network]] are the two largest divisions of The Bayat Group, which also owns and operates the following companies:
* Ariana Network Services<ref name="Ariana Network Services">{{cite web | title=Official Website of Ariana Network Services | publisher=ans.af | date=2017-07-30 |url=http://ans.af}}</ref> * Bayat Energy * Best Jobs * Fine Media Consulting Group * Fine Mineral Water
For over a decade, The Bayat Group has championed building the capabilities its workforce—and supported [[Afghan]] economic development—by dedicating significant resources to developing the educational, entrepreneurial and administrative capabilities of its executive, managerial and front line staffs. The Bayat Group provides scholarship assistance to employees attending Afghan Universities. In addition, The Company's internal professional development program offers over fifty-two professional development courses.
==Bayat Foundation== In 2005, Ehsan Bayat and his wife, Fatema Bayat, established The Bayat Foundation<ref>{{cite web | title = The Bayat Foundation - Making a Difference in Afghanistan | publisher = Worldpress.org | date = 2006-10-18 | url = http://www.worldpress.org/Asia/2526.cfm | accessdate =2008-01-20 }}</ref> but also among [[Afghan refugees]] in [[Pakistan]].<ref>Esalat - ''People's democratic broadcaster of Afghanistan''...[http://www.esalat.org/images/ehsanullah%20bayat%20kist%20.htm Link], retrieved December 2007</ref>. The Bayat Foundation has sponsored more than 300 projects dedicated to improving the health and welfare of Afghans, including the construction of thirteen maternity hospitals which have treated more than 1,500,000 Afghan women and children.
== Awards and honors ==
Ehsan Bayat has received the following awards and honors, in recognition of his achievements as a Business Leader and Philanthropist:
* 2018: Delivered the keynote address for the Afghan-American Chamber of Commerce (AACC) Business Conference in April<ref>{{cite news|title=Bayat Group Founder and Chairman Dr. Ehsan Bayat Delivers Keynote Address to Afghan American Chamber of Commerce Annual Business Conference|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/bayat-group-founder-and-chairman-dr-ehsan-bayat-delivers-keynote-address-to-afghan-american-chamber-of-commerce-annual-business-conference-300638577.html}}</ref> * 2016: New Jersey Institute of Technology Alumni Achievement Award<ref name="Alumni Achievement Award">{{cite news | title=Dr. Ehsan Bayat, Founder And Chairman Of The Bayat Group, Presented 2016 Alumni Achievement Award From The New Jersey Institute Of Technology | work=Prnewswire.com | date=May 23, 2016 |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/dr-ehsan-bayat-founder-and-chairman-of-the-bayat-group-presented-2016-alumni-achievement-award-from-the-new-jersey-institute-of-technology-300273194.html}}</ref> * 2014: Chosen as Radio Azadi's Nowruz Man of the Year in recognition of exceptional individual contributions to Peace, Democracy and Culture in Afghanistan<ref name="Nowruz Man of the Year">{{cite news | title=Ehsanollah Bayat Selected As Radio Azadi's Nowruz Man Of The Year; Recognizes Exceptional Individual Contributions To Peace, Democracy And Culture In Afghanistan | work=Prnewswire.com | date=March 26, 2014 |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/ehsanollah-bayat-selected-as-radio-azadis-nowruz-man-of-the-year-recognizes-exceptional-individual-contributions-to-peace-democracy-and-culture-in-afghanistan-252466331.html}}</ref> * 2012: Honorary Degree of Doctor of Humane Letters from American University of Afghanistan for his works<ref name="Honorary Degree of Doctor of Humane Letters">{{cite web | title=Honorary Degree Recipients at AUAF | work=auaf.edu.af | date=May 26, 2012 |url=https://www.auaf.edu.af/about/people/board-of-trustees/honorary-degree-recipients-at-auaf/}}</ref> * 2011: Excellence for his commitment to Afghanistan presented by 4,000 AWCC employees * 2010: Mahatma Gandhi Humanitarian Award from the Friends of the South Asian American Communities<ref name="Mahatma Gandhi Humanitarian Award">{{cite news | title=Ehsan Bayat Receives Mahatma Gandhi Humanitarian Award | work=wn.com | date=September 22, 2010 |url=https://article.wn.com/view/2010/09/23/Ehsan_Bayat_Receives_Mahatma_Gandhi_Humanitarian_Award/}}</ref> * 2008: Man of the Year Award from Afghan-Americans in California * 2008: Corporate Social Responsibility Award from the Canada-Afghanistan Business Council<ref name="Corporate Social Responsibility Award">{{cite news | title=Canada-Afghanistan Business Council Recognizes Ehsan Bayat, Entrepreneur and Humanitarian, for Corporate Social Contributions in Afghanistan | work=newswire.ca | date=October 17, 2008 |url=http://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/canada-afghanistan-business-council-recognizes-ehsan-bayat-entrepreneur-and-humanitarian-for-corporate-social-contributions-in-afghanistan-536732051.html}}</ref> * 2007: Man of the Year Award from ''Sitara'' magazine * 2007: Humanitarian of the Year award from ''Zeba'' Magazine * 2007: First recipient of the Businessman of the Year Award by the Afghan-American Chamber of Commerce in Washington, D.C.<ref name="Businessman of the Year Award">{{cite news | title=Ehsan Bayat gets Businessman of the year award | work=afghanembassyjp.org | date=November 15, 2007 |url=http://www.afghanembassyjp.org/en/news/?an=578}}</ref> * 2006: National Human Rights Award awarded by the Afghanistan Human Rights Association by President [[Hamid Karzai]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{notability|1=Biographies|date=February 2018}}
{{COI|date=October 2017}} '''Ekow Mensah''' is a Ghanaian social entrepreneur and speaker<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thebftonline.com/features/media/24775/ekow-mensah-speaks-at-2017-africa-dialogues-conference.html|title=Ekow Mensah speaks at 2017 Africa dialogues conference {{!}} Media - Features|website=thebftonline.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref> who is founder and CEO of The African Network of Entrepreneurs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/business/TANOE-celebrates-60-Outstanding-SMEs-in-Ghana-553020|title=TANOE celebrates 60 Outstanding SMEs in Ghana|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref>
==Early life== Mensah was born in Takoradi in the Western Region of Ghana. He obtained a degree in Mathematics from the [[Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology]] in Kumasi, Ghana.
==Career== As the CEO of The African Network of Entrepreneurs, he oversees 5 networks<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ugweeklynews.com/tanoe-celebrates-60-outstanding-smes-ghana/|title=TANOE Celebrates 60 Outstanding SMEs in Ghana - UgWeekly News|website=ugweeklynews.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref><ref>https://ucctalks.com/news/top-100-student-entrepreneurs-ghana-according-syenet/</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/regional/TANOE-Launches-the-Girl-Empowered-454832|title=TANOE Launches the Girl Empowered|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.yfmghana.com/2016/12/01/caroline-sampson-efya-wiyaala-make-100-most-influential-ghanaian-women-list/|title=Caroline Sampson, Efya, Wiyaala Make 100 Most Influential Ghanaian Women list|last=Ghana|first=YFM|work=YFM Ghana|access-date=2017-10-03|language=en}}</ref> and 6 projects which are actively involved in various impact activities across Ghana. The African Network of Entrepreneurs holds a membership of over 1750 entrepreneurs across Africa primarily in Ghana, Nigeria, South Africa, Uganda, Liberia, Kenya and Zambia. He also recently launched Ghana's first creative arts hub and co-working space, known as the TANOE Hub which provides space and resources to creatives in Accra, Ghana. Ekow was recently appointed by Premium Bank Ghana Ltd to head its HelpStation initiative<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://citibusinessnews.com/index.php/2017/07/21/premium-bank-launch-5million-integrated-credit-facility/|title=Premium Bank launch 5Million Integrated Credit Facility for Startups - Ghana Business News|date=2017-07-21|work=Ghana Business News|access-date=2017-10-03|language=en-US}}</ref> and also chairs the Board of the Ghana Startup Awards.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.myjoyonline.com/business/2017/July-14th/joybusiness-receives-award-at-ghana-startup-awards-2017.php|title=JoyBusiness receives award at Ghana Startup Awards 2017|date=2017-07-14|access-date=2017-10-03|language=en-US}}</ref> He is also an independent consultant with [[British Council]] Ghana and DwellWorks, USA and mentors<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ameyawdebrah.com/ekow-mensah-hosts-1st-igniting-dreams-conference-april-15/|title=Ekow Mensah hosts the 1st Igniting Dreams Conference, April 15 - AmeyawDebrah.Com|date=2017-04-12|work=AmeyawDebrah.Com|access-date=2017-10-03|language=en-US}}</ref> participants of the Regional YALI West Africa programme and students of [[Ashesi University]].
His article<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nigeriatoday.ng/2016/11/opinion-igniting-dreams-the-trump-way/|title=Opinion: Igniting dreams the Trump way — Nigeria Today|date=2016-11-10|work=Nigeria Today|access-date=2017-10-03|language=en-GB}}</ref> on President [[Donald Trump]] was highly published and recommended across Africa.
==Recognition== In 2015, Mensah was ranked among the 50 Most Influential Young Ghanaians<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.peacefmonline.com/pages/local/social/201601/265548.php|title=LIST: Fifty (50) Most Influential Young Ghanaians|last=Online|first=Peace FM|website=m.peacefmonline.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref> by Avance Media and was subsequently recognised by [[Coca-Cola]] among 60 Young Leaders in Ghana.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://citifmonline.com/2017/04/06/youth-and-sports-minister-lauds-coca-cola-for-rewarding-60-young-achievers/|title=Youth and Sports Minister lauds Coca-Cola for rewarding 60 young achievers|last=Adogla-Bessa|first=Delali|date=2017-04-06|work=Ghana News|access-date=2017-10-03|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mensah, Ekow}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Ghanaian businesspeople]] [[Category:Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology alumni]]

{{orphan|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = FAX.PLUS | logo = Faxplus-logo.png | logo_size = 180px | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | owner = Alohi SA | industry = [[Internet fax]], [[Telecommunication]] | founded = | area_served = Worldwide | hq_location_city = [[Geneva, Switzerland]] | website = [https://FAX.PLUS/ FAX.PLUS] }} '''FAX.PLUS''' is a [[cloud-based]] online fax service based in [[Geneva, Switzerland]] that offers individuals and corporates a solution to send and receive fax online.<ref>{{cite news |title=Non, le fax n’est pas (tout à fait) mort ! |url=http://www.europe1.fr/economie/non-le-fax-nest-pas-tout-a-fait-mort-2842900 |accessdate=21 November 2018 |publisher=[[Europe 1]] |language=fr-FR}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Send Faxes From the Web: Three Services Tested |url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/249237/send_faxes_from_the_web_three_services_tested.html |accessdate=21 November 2018 |publisher=[[PC World]]|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=How to Send a Fax from Your Smartphone |url=https://lifehacker.com/how-to-send-a-fax-from-your-smartphone-1744654345 |accessdate=21 November 2018 |publisher=[[Lifehacker]]}}</ref> FAX.PLUS is a sub-organization of Alohi<ref>{{cite web |title=Business overview of Alohi |url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/alohi |publisher=[[Crunchbase]] |accessdate=21 November 2018}}</ref> which is founded on 2015 and incubated at FONGIT.
==Platforms== FAX.PLUS is a [[cross-platform]] online fax service that enables users to send and receive fax from web, mobile, email or even Google [[G Suite]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Fax Server Software FAX.PLUS |url=https://www.capterra.com/p/173529/FAX-PLUS/ |accessdate=21 November 2018 |publisher=[[Capterra]]}}</ref> The app is available for both [[IOS mobile app|iOS]] and [[Android platform|Android platforms]] and is for those who need to send and receive fax from their mobile devices. The FAX.PLUS web application comes with a user-friendly interface and without ads.<ref>{{cite news |title=These are the only free services you should consider for faxing documents |url=https://www.dailydot.com/debug/free-fax-services/ |accessdate=21 November 2018 |publisher=[[The Daily Dot]] |date=9 June 2018}}</ref>
===Google integration=== FAX.PLUS supports the G Suite add-on which allows the user to send fax from [[Google Docs]], [[Google Sheets]], and the [[Chrome extension]] to send fax from [[Chrome browser]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Fax your document online |url=https://gsuite.google.com/marketplace/app/faxplus_fax_your_document/657386331374 |accessdate=21 November 2018 |work=gsuite.google.com |publisher=[[G Suite]] |language=en}}</ref>
===API=== The FAX.PLUS [[Representational state transfer|REST]]-based API enables third party developers and organizations to integrate online fax functionalities into their own software or program.<ref>{{cite web |title=Repositories on GitHub |url=https://github.com/alohi |publisher=[[GitHub]] |accessdate=21 November 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
===Slack integration=== With FAX.PLUS Slack integration, users get notified of received faxes and the status of sent faxes in their [[Slack (software)|Slack workspace]].<ref>{{cite news |title=FAX.PLUS app integration |url=https://slack.com/apps/ADJ59D37A-faxplus |accessdate=15 November 2018 |publisher=[[Slack (software)]]}}</ref>
==Features== According to its website, the Fax files at [[Representational state transfer|rest]] are encrypted using 256-bit [[Advanced Encryption Standard]] (AES).<ref>{{cite news |title=The Best Online Fax Services of 2018 |url=https://www.business.com/categories/online-fax-services/ |accessdate=21 November 2018 |publisher=[[Business.com]]}}</ref> FAX.PLUS has fax numbers available from 44 countries, and it can send faxes to over 150 countries.<ref>{{cite news |title=Best Online Fax Services for Small Business |url=https://www.businessnewsdaily.com/5706-best-online-fax-services.html |accessdate=21 November 2018 |publisher=[[Business News Daily]]}}</ref> According to, [[:de:teltarif.de|Teltarif (magazine)]], it comes with a simple and intuitive interface and users can access all the functionalities easily.<ref>{{cite web |title=Fax.Plus im Test: Faxe senden & empfangen per Smartphone (Update) |url=https://www.teltarif.de/fax-plus-app-smartphone-test/news/73431.html |publisher=[[:de:teltarif.de|teltarif.de]] |accessdate=21 November 2018 |language=de}}</ref> FAX.PLUS also includes a feature to use the smartphone’s camera to scan documents and add [[digital signature]] to them.<ref>{{cite web |title=64% of online faxes sent on FAX.PLUS are sent via smartphones |url=https://www.prweb.com/releases/2017/03/prweb14135608.htm |publisher=[[Vocus (software)]] |accessdate=21 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Sommario marzo 2018 |url=https://www.pcprofessionale.it/magazine/sommario-marzo-2018/ |accessdate=21 November 2018 |publisher=[[:it:PC Professionale|PC Professionale (magazine)]] |date=1 March 2018 |language=it-IT}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Companies based in Geneva]] [[Category:Companies of Switzerland]] [[Category:Telecommunication industry]] [[Category:Internet fax]]

'''George Paraskevaides''' (1916 – December 5, 2007) was a [[Cyprus|Cypriot]] philanthropist and [[businessman]] who focused on the [[construction]] business in [[Europe]] and the [[Middle East]].<ref name=iht>{{cite news |first=Albert |last=Aji |title=Cypriot construction magnate and philanthropist George Paraskevaides dies at 91 |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/12/05/europe/EU-GEN-Cyprus-Obit-Paraskevaides.php |agency=[[Associated Press]] |newspaper=[[International Herald Tribune]] |date=December 5, 2007 |accessdate=December 8, 2007}} {{Dead link|date=June 2018}}</ref> Paraskevaides was one of the co-founders of [[Joannou & Paraskevaides]], an important international construction firm based in [[Cyprus]], with fellow Cypriot, Stelios Ioannou.<ref name=iht/>
==Early life== Paraskevaides was born in [[Athens, Greece]], in 1916.<ref name=iht/> His family moved to Cyprus when he was very young.<ref name=iht/> He studied architecture at [[Politecnico di Milano]] in [[Milan, Italy]].<ref name=iht/>
==Career== Paraskevaides joined forces with Stelios Ioannou following the end of [[World War II]]. Together the two partners founded the [[Joannou & Paraskevaides]] company, which is better known as J&P.<ref name=iht/> Their company would eventually grow into a major international construction giant, with dozens of projects throughout [[Europe]], the [[Middle East]], [[Africa]] and [[Asia]].<ref name=iht/>
He was also well known for his [[philanthropic]] work. He helped to build an [[organ transplant]] center in Nicosia, Cyprus.<ref name=iht/> He also paid to send children for medical treatment in the [[United States]].<ref name=iht/>
Paraskevaides received a number of awards and recognitions for his work in both business and philanthropy. He was inducted into the [[Order of the British Empire]] by [[Queen Elizabeth II]].<ref name=iht/> He was also awarded the [[Saint Marcus Medal]] from the [[Holy See|Vatican]].<ref name=iht/>
==Death== George Paraskevaides died at the [[London Clinic]] in [[London]] on December 5, 2007, at the age of 91.<ref name=iht/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{cite news |url=http://www.financialmirror.com/more_news.php?id=9178&type=st&nt=Politics |title=Cyprus construction tycoon George Paraskevaides dies |date=December 5, 2007 |newspaper=[[Financial Mirror]]}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}} *{{cite web |url=http://news.pseka.net/index.php?module=article&id=7781 |title=State funeral for Cyprus construction tycoon George Paraskevaides |date=December 12, 2007 |website=PSEKA.net}} *{{cite web |url=https://www.geni.com/people/George-Paraskevaides-O-B-E/6000000011033054452 |title=George Paraskevaides, O.B.E. |website=Geni.com}}
