{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = Baron | name = Viktor Gutmann | honorific_suffix = von Gelse und Belišće | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_size = 250px | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1891|10|03}} | birth_place = [[Belišće]], [[Austro-Hungarian Empire]], (now [[Croatia]]) | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1946|02|17|1891|10|03}} | death_place = [[Zagreb]], [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|SFR Yugoslavia]], (now [[Croatia]]) | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = [[Croatia]] | education = [[Mechanical engineering]] | alma_mater = [[Vienna University of Technology]] | occupation = [[Businessman]], [[Engineer]] | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = [[Belišće]] | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | denomination = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = [[Capital punishment|death penalty]] | criminal_status = | spouse = Luise ([[Married and maiden names|née]] Bloch-Bauer) | partner = | children = Francis
Nelly [[Principality of Auersperg|of Auersperg]] | parents = Alfred Gutmann
Ottilie Gutmann ([[Married and maiden names|née]] Pollak von Rudin) | relatives = [[Edmund Gutmann]] (uncle)
Ernest (brother)
Otto (brother)
[[Maria Altmann]] (sister in law) | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} [[Baron]] '''Viktor Gutmann''' von Gelse und Belišće (3 October 1891 – 17 February 1946) was [[Croatian people|Croatian]] [[Nobility|nobleman]] and industrialist. == Early life == Baron Gutmann was born in [[Belišće]] on 3 October 1891 to a noble Croatian [[Jews|Jewish]] family Gutmann. His father, Baron Alfred Gutmann von Gelse und Belišće (born 1857), was the youngest son of Salamon Heinrich Gutman and brother of Baron [[Edmund Gutmann]]. Whole Gutmann family was awarded with a [[hereditary peer]] ''Baron von Gelse und Belišće''.{{hr icon}} Obzor (Tjedni Magazin Večernjeg lista); ''Tragedija bogate židovske obitelji Gutmann''; broj 451, 10. lipanj, 2012. His mother was Ottilie ([[Married and maiden names|née]] Pollak von Rudin) Gutmann. Baron Gutmann was married to Luise Bloch-Bauer. His wife Luise the daughter of Marie Therese ([[née]] Bauer 1874–1961) and Gustav Bloch (1862-1938). Luise was sister of [[Maria Altmann]] and niece of [[Adele Bloch-Bauer]], a wealthy member of [[Vienna|Viennese]] society and a patron and close friend of [[Gustav Klimt]]. == Great War and aftermath == He graduated as a mechanical engineer at the [[Vienna University of Technology]].{{Cite news|last=|first=|coauthors=|title=Tragedija bogate židovske obitelji Gutmann|pages=|publisher=[[Večernji list]]|date=2012-06-09|url=http://www.vecernji.hr/vijesti/tragedija-bogate-zidovske-obitelji-gutmann-clanak-418004|accessdate=2012-09-12|language=hr}} After graduation he served in the [[Austro-Hungarian Army]] on the [[Eastern Front (World War I)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War I]]. Baron Gutmann was awarded with [[Military Merit Medal (Austria-Hungary)|Military Merit Medal]] and several others valor medals. After the war he returned to Belišće to work at his family company "H.S. Gutmann". His grandfather Salamon established the wood-processing company "H.S. Gutmann" in [[Hungary]]. At first Gutmann worked under his cousin Artur Gutmann who was the oldest son of Edmund Gutmann. After his cousin death, Baron Gutmann and his brother Ernest took over the company. Baron Gutmann and his brother have expanded the company, build up and developed Belišće. Gutmann family was very loved and popular in Belišće and among company employees.[http://www.croatia.org/crown/articles/10058/1/Nelly-Auersperg-distinguished-Canadian-scientist-educated-also-in-Zagreb-Croatia.html Nelly Auersperg distinguished Canadian scientist educated also in Zagreb Croatia] == During Second World War == During [[World War II]] Baron Gutmann company was [[Nationalization|nationalised]] by the [[Independent State of Croatia]] regime. As Jews, in 1943, Baron Gutmann, his wife and children were arrested and taken by [[Ustaše]] to prison at Savska street. Baron Gutmann and his family managed to survive the [[Holocaust]]. After the war Baron Gutmann, as an idealist, returned to Belišće to assist in the reconstruction of Yugoslavia. == Capture, trial and death == On 17 November 1945 Baron Gutmann was arrested by the newly founded communist regime of [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|SFR Yugoslavia]] as a "capitalist and aristocrat" under false charges of collaboration with the [[Nazis]]. After two days of the trail at County Peoples Court in Zagreb Baron Gutmann was sentenced to death on 23 November 1945.{{cite web |url=http://www.telegram.hr/price/ne-znamo-kako-je-svima-promaklo-ali-princeza-iz-kanade-u-zagrebu-je-srusila-je-komunisticku-presudu-zbog-koje-je-njezin-tata-bogatas-iz-belisca-strijeljan/ |title=Ne znamo kako je svima promaklo, ali princeza iz Kanade u Zagrebu je srušila komunističku presudu zbog koje je njezin tata, bogataš iz Belišća, strijeljan |accessdate=12 August 2016 |work=telegram.hr}} Final verdict was confirmed by Supreme Court of [[PR Croatia]] on 16 January 1946. He was executed in 1946 by the Communist regime in Zagreb. == Family == Baron Gutmann and his wife Luise had a son Franjo and daughter Nelly. Daughter Nelly was born in [[Vienna]] on 13 December 1928. Nelly enrolled in medical school at the [[University of Zagreb]] in 1946, where she studied for three years till 1949. In 1950 Nelly moved to [[Vancouver, British Columbia]], [[Canada]] where she married in 1955 to Johananes Weikhardt [[Principality of Auersperg|of Auersperg]], a descendant of [[Heinrich Joseph Johann of Auersperg]] and grand-grandnephew of two [[Minister-President of Cisleithania|Minister-Presidents of Austria]], [[Prince Karl of Auersperg|Karl]] and [[Prince Adolf of Auersperg|Adolf]] of Auersperg.http://www.almanachdegotha.org/id66.html{{cite web |last=Marek |first=Miroslav |url=http://genealogy.euweb.cz/auersperg/auersperg7.html |title= auersperg/auersperg7.html |publisher=genealogy.euweb.cz}}{{Self-published source|date=November 2016}}{{Better source|date=November 2016}} After completing a Ph.D. in cell biology at the [[University of British Columbia]], Nelly assumed a position there as Associate Professor in 1968. == Legacy == In June 2016 Council of the County Court in Zagreb accepted request for review of Gutmann's trial and quashed the verdict from 1946. The review of trial of Gutmann was requested by Nelly, daughter of Gutmann. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== {{Refbegin|30em}} {{refend}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gutmann, Edmund}} [[Category:1891 births]] [[Category:1946 deaths]] [[Category:People from Belišće]] [[Category:People from the Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia]] [[Category:Croatian Jews]] [[Category:Austro-Hungarian Jews]] [[Category:Croatian Austro-Hungarians]] [[Category:Croatian people of Hungarian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Croatian businesspeople]] [[Category:Croatian nobility]] [[Category:Barons of Croatia]] [[Category:Croatian people of World War I]] [[Category:Executed Croatian people]] [[Category:Croatian prisoners sentenced to death]]

{{Infobox person | name = Zibusiso Mkhwanazi | image = ZibusisoMkhwanazi.jpg | caption = Zibusiso Mkhwanazi | birth_place = [[South Africa]] | occupation = Entrepreneur |awards = [[Young Global Leaders|World Economic Forum Young Global Leaders]] (2010), Top Young ICT Entrepreneur in Africa Award (2008) }}
'''Zibusiso Mkhwanazi''' (born 10 June 1983, Soweto, South Africa) is Group CEO of M&N Brands and co-founder of Avatar,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.avataragency.co.za/|title=Home of Avatar Agency - AVATAR|website=AVATAR|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-14}}</ref> South Africa’s largest black owned and managed advertising agency.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://citizen.co.za/news/1804939/brand-south-africa-website-down-ceo-wont-be-bullied/ |title= Brand South Africa website down, CEO won’t be ‘bullied’|accessdate=February 2, 2018}}</ref> Avatar won Financial Mail’s AdFocus medium sized agency of the year 2016 and were a finalist in 2017.<ref>http://www.avataragency.co.za/2016/11/24/adfocus-medium-sized-agency-for-2016/</ref> A World Economic Forum Young Global Leader, Mkhwanazi is now building an African owned agency network through his investment company, M&N Brands.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cn.weforum.org/people/zibusiso-mkhwanazi/|title=Zibusiso Mkhwanazi {{!}} 世界经济论坛|website=世界经济论坛|access-date=2018-04-14}}</ref><ref>https://cn.weforum.org/people/zibusiso-mkhwanazi/</ref> Mkhwanazi is also the founder of David’s League, a Christian based business mentorship program designed to uplift and empower young entrepreneurs from disadvantaged backgrounds in their business journeys.
Mkhwanazi is a Trustee of the National Economic and Education Trust (NEET),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://neet.co.za/chairman-viewpoint |title= National Economic Education Trust|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref> which has provided over 4,200 scholarships to underprivileged ICT students.<ref>[citation needed]</ref> Born in 1980, he is the founder of David’s League,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.davidsleague.co.za/ |title= David's League|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref> a Christianity-based mentorship programme designed to uplift and empower young entrepreneurs from disadvantaged backgrounds in their business pursuits.
== Career == Mkhwanazi started his first business, Csonke, a web design company, at the age of 17 (in 2000). Csonke then merged with Krazyboyz in 2007 and Mkhwanazi served as Executive Chairman until July 2010, developing and overseeing growth, strategy and marketing for both the Cape Town and Johannesburg offices.<ref>{{cite web|author=IT-Online |url=http://www.it-online.co.za/2007/01/26/bee-deal-creates-major-digital-agency/ |title=BEE deal creates major digital agency « News « IT-Online |publisher=It-online.co.za |date=2007-01-26 |accessdate=2012-01-13}}</ref> He then took on the role of CEO from July 2010 – December 2011.<ref>https://www.itweb.co.za/content/VgZey7JVdLO7djX9</ref><ref>http://it-online.co.za/2007/01/26/bee-deal-creates-major-digital-agency/</ref>
In January 2012, Mkhwanazi went into partnership with Veli Ngubane<ref>http://www.avataragency.co.za/2017/11/01/veli-ngubane-cco-avatar-ad-agency-history-selling-bright-ideas/</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=VELI NGUBANE, A FOUNDING PARTNER OF DIGITAL MARKETING AGENCY AVATAR|url=https://soundcloud.com/powerfm987/veli-ngubane-a-founding-partner-of-digital-marketing-agency-avatar|language=en|accessdate=2018-05-07}}</ref> to found Avatar which has won numerous awards (AdFocus) including most digitally integrated agency (MarkLives)<ref>http://www.marklives.com/2017/02/agency-leaders-2016-most-digitally-integrated-ad-agency-in-jozi/</ref> and also the agency that has done the most to drive transformation in the SA industry (MarkLives).<ref>http://www.marklives.com/2018/03/agencyleaders2017-south-africa-agency-diversity-and-transformation/</ref> Avatar opened their Cape Town office<ref>http://www.avataragency.co.za/2016/02/09/avatar-invades-cape-town/</ref> in 2016 and have won numerous accounts such as H&M<ref>http://www.marklives.com/2018/05/exclusive-avatar-ct-wins-hm/</ref> and Chevron.<ref>http://www.avataragency.co.za/2016/02/02/avatar-wins-the-chevron-sa-account-opens-cape-town-office/</ref>
He also served as Chairman of ARM advertising and design in 2009, as well as Chairman of The Red quarter Brand Design August 2010 – November 2013.<ref>http://www.theredquarter.co.za/index.php</ref>
Mkhwanazi is the majority shareholder in M&N Brands, with partner Veli Ngubane,<ref name=":0" /> an investment company building an African owned agency network.<ref name=":0">{{Citation|title=Ayabonga Cawe, Power FM interview with Veli Ngubane, a founding partner of digital marketing agency Avatar|date=5 April 2018|url=https://soundcloud.com/powerfm987/veli-ngubane-a-founding-partner-of-digital-marketing-agency-avatar|language=en|accessdate=2018-05-07}}</ref> In 2017 they acquired Mela Events, a gold-Loerie award winning events company with clients such as Standard Bank and Nando’s.<ref>http://www.marklives.com/radar/mn-brands-buys-mela-events/</ref> In 2017, the 33-year-old Financial Mail ADFocus awards created the industry’s first transformation award at Mkhwanazi’s urging, which was sponsored by M&N Brands.<ref>https://mg.co.za/article/2018-01-05-00-were-transforming-the-milky-way</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avataragency.co.za/2014/09/05/what-is-content-marketing-interview-with-zibusiso-mkhwanazi-part-2/|title=What is Content Marketing? Interview with Zibusiso Mkhwanazi - Part 2 - AVATAR|website=www.avataragency.co.za|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-03}}</ref>
== Education == Bramley primary school, Bedfordview High School, NDip Information Technology (2005) and Dip Corporate Law (2006) at the University of Johannesburg, Foundations for Leadership in the 21<sup>st</sup> Century (2012) Yale and Global Leadership and Public Policy for the 21<sup>st</sup> Century (2013) at Harvard.<ref>https://news.yale.edu/2012/10/12/yale-hosts-program-young-global-leaders</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox Officeholder |name = Étienne Davignon |image = Etienne Davignon.jpg |office = European Commissioner for [[European Commissioner for Industry and Entrepreneurship|Industrial Affairs]] and [[European Commissioner for Energy|Energy]] |president = [[Gaston Thorn]] |term_start = 6 January 1981 |term_end = 6 January 1985 |predecessor = Himself ([[European Commissioner for Internal Market and Services|Internal Market]], [[European Commissioner for Taxation and Customs Union, Audit and Anti-Fraud|Customs Union]] and Industrial Affairs)
[[Guido Brunner]] (Energy, the [[European Commissioner for Research, Innovation and Science|Science and Research]]) |successor = [[Karl-Heinz Narjes]](Industry, [[European Commissioner for Digital Agenda|Information Technology]], [[European Commissioner for Research, Innovation and Science|Science and Research]])
[[Nicolas Mosar]] (Energy) |office2 = European Commissioner for the [[European Commissioner for Internal Market and Services|Internal Market]], the [[European Commissioner for Taxation and Customs Union, Audit and Anti-Fraud|Customs Union]] and [[European Commissioner for Industry and Entrepreneurship|Industrial Affairs]] |president2 = [[Roy Jenkins]] |term_start2 = 6 January 1977 |term_end2 = 6 January 1981 |predecessor2 = [[Finn Olav Gundelach]] (Internal Market and the Customs Union)
[[Cesidio Guazzaroni]] (Industry and [[European Commissioner for Research, Innovation and Science|Technology]]) |successor2 = [[Karl-Heinz Narjes]] (Internal Market, [[European Commissioner for Industry and Entrepreneurship|Industrial Innovation]], the Customs Union, the [[European Commissioner for the Environment|Environment]], [[European Commissioner for Health and Consumer Policy|Consumer Protection]] and [[European Commissioner for Energy|Nuclear Safety]])
Himself (Industrial Affairs and [[European Commissioner for Energy|Energy]]) |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1932|10|4|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Budapest]], [[Kingdom of Hungary (1920–1946)|Hungary]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Centre démocrate humaniste|Humanist Democratic Centre]] |alma_mater = [[Catholic University of Leuven (1834–1968)|Catholic University of Louvain]] }} Count '''Étienne Davignon''' (born 4 October 1932 in [[Budapest]], [[Kingdom of Hungary (1920–1946)|Hungary]]) is a [[Belgium|Belgian]] politician, businessman, and former vice-president of the [[European Commission]]. ==Career== After receiving a Doctorate of Law from the [[Catholic University of Leuven (1834–1968)|Catholic University of Louvain]], Davignon joined the Belgian Foreign Ministry, in 1959, and within two years had become an [[attaché]] under [[Paul-Henri Spaak]], then [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Belgium)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]].{{cite web|url=http://www.csreurope.org/pages/en/davignon.html|title=''Etienne Davignon, President of CSR Europe''|publisher=CSR Europe|accessdate=30 January 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100202011840/http://www.csreurope.org/pages/en/davignon.html|archivedate=2 February 2010|df=dmy-all}} He remained in Belgian government until 1965. In 1970, he chaired the committee of experts which produced the [[Davignon report]] on foreign policy for Europe.{{cite web|url=http://www.friendsofeurope.org/Aboutus/Whoweare/PraesidiumandTrustees/tabid/529/Default.aspx|title=''Friends of Europe – President''|publisher=[[Friends of Europe]]|accessdate=30 January 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100420001026/http://www.friendsofeurope.org/Aboutus/Whoweare/PraesidiumandTrustees/tabid/529/Default.aspx|archivedate=20 April 2010|df=dmy-all}} Davignon later became the first head of the [[International Energy Agency]], from 1974 to 1977, before becoming a member of the European Commission, of which he was vice-president from 1981 till 1985. From 1989 to 2001, he was chairman of the Belgian bank [[Société Générale de Belgique]], which is now part of the French supplier [[Suez (company)|Suez]] and was not an arm of the French bank [[Société Générale]], but a Belgian institution. He is now Vice Chairman of Suez subsidiary, Suez-Tractebel.{{cite web|url=https://people.forbes.com/profile/etienne-f-davignon/36995|title=''Etienne F. Davignon''|work=Forbes |accessdate=30 January 2010}} As chairman of Société Générale de Belgique, he was a member of the [[European Round Table of Industrialists]]. He is the current co-chairman of the EU-Japan Business Dialogue Round Table, chairman of the Paul-Henri Spaak Foundation, president of the EGMONT – Royal Institute for International Relations, chairman of CSR Europe, chairman of the European Academy of Business in Society and was chairman of the annual [[Bilderberg Group|Bilderberg conference]] from 1998 to 2001.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4290944.stm |title=Inside the secretive Bilderberg Group |publisher=BBC News |date=29 September 2005}} He is a member of the Steering Committee of the Bilderberg Group.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bilderbergmeetings.org/governance.html|title=Steering Committee|work=bilderbergmeetings.org|publisher=[[Bilderberg Group]]|accessdate=2014-02-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311013611/http://www.bilderbergmeetings.org/governance.html|archivedate=11 March 2014|df=dmy-all}} Davignon is the chairman of the board of directors of [[Brussels Airlines]],{{cite web|url=http://company.brusselsairlines.com/en_be/corp/our-company/organisation.aspx|title=''Brussels Airlines – Organisation''|publisher=[[Brussels Airlines]]|accessdate=30 January 2010}} which he co-founded after the bankruptcy of [[Sabena]]. He is also a member of the board of numerous Belgian companies, and is the chairman of the board of directors and of the General Assembly of the [[ICHEC Brussels Management School]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ichec.be/modules/kb_pages/subject.php?subject_id=91 |title=Assemblée générale et conseil d’administration |publisher=ICHEC |accessdate=28 August 2011}} On 26 January 2004, Davignon was given the honorary title of ''Minister of State'', giving him a seat on the Crown Council. Davignon is a crucial member of the Strategic Advisory Panel of The European Business Awards. He is a member of the [[Cercle Gaulois]] and a member of the Advisory Board of the [[Itinera Institute]] [[think tank]]. He is also President of the [[Brussels]]-based think tank [[Friends of Europe]]. ==Family== Étienne's grandfather, [[Julien Davignon]], also served in the government of Belgium, being Minister for Foreign Affairs in 1914, at the outbreak of World War I.{{Fact|date=April 2011}} == Honours == * Minister of State, by Royal Decree. * Knight Grand Cross of the [[Legion of Honour]].
